content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 specifies the coin's design and specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.5 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins issued under this Act shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden. Each coin will have a designated value and inscription. The coins issued under this Act shall bear inscriptions of the year `1995', the words `Liberty', `In God We Trust', `United States of America', and `E Pluribus Unum'. They will also have a designated value and be legal tender. The coins issued under this Act shall be legal tender, as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. Selection of design for the coins. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The issuance of SEC-5 coins. Quality of coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint Facility - Not more than 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this Act. Period of Issuance - The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act during the period beginning on January 1, 1995, and ending on. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act during the period beginning on January 1, 1995, and ending on December 31, 1995. -S-E-C-. -6-. -S-A-L-E -O-F -C-O-I-N-S-. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the sum of the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in subsection (d) with respect to such coins, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales - The Secretary shall. The Secretary shall make bulk sales of the authorized coins at a reasonable discount and accept prepaid orders for the coins before issuance. The Secretary shall accept prepaid orders for authorized coins prior to issuance, with sales at a reasonable discount. All sales will include a surcharge of $10 per coin. General waiver of procurement regulations. No provision of law governing procurement or public contracts applies to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. Nothing in this section relieves any person entering into a contract under this Act from complying with any law relating to equal employment opportunity. Distribution of surcharges is covered in Section 8. Distribution of surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. Audits are covered in Section 9. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures. This Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 coins made of 90% silver and 10% copper, with a design featuring a rose and the United States Botanic Garden. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and bear the year "1995" on them. The $1 coins authorized by the Secretary of the Treasury will feature a rose and the United States Botanic Garden design. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. They will bear inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum", along with the year "1995". The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at one designated Mint facility from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, a surcharge of $10, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins authorized under this Act before issuance, with sales at a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for Act implementation, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 states that surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. The Secretary will promptly pay all surcharges from coin sales to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. The Comptroller General of the United States can audit the National Fund's expenditures related to these payments.
